review_title: Great Place for a Student to Work
pros: Excellent coworkers and flexible about letting you change schedules to study
cons: None really, all of my campus jobs were great

pros: Plymouth is a neat town, beautiful scenery, bus to Boston, great nearby skiing
cons: Low pay, unresponsive administration, very low faculty morale, entitled students bent on partying rather than learning, low academic standards, everything moving to contract and lots of employment precarity, LOTS of turnover without explanation and people suddenly leaving. Frequently hear racist and sexist comments as par for the course, definitely a PWI. The res halls are nightmarish, from all accounts. If you are a tenured professor it's plain sailing but for all the teaching lecturers and teaching faculty and staff it's a different reality. The leadership used to care about the culture and family nature of the place, but that is long gone, which is really sad.

pros: Location to white mountains for hiking and skiing.
cons: Poor management that can not make basic decisions. Treat employees poorly and no real growth. Employee turn over and position vacancies are high. Current employees are expected to take on double the work without any compensation.

review_title: Flexible but high workload and low pay
job_title: Academic Operations Manager in Plymouth, NH
pros: Flexible schedule Opportunity for remote work Family oriented
cons: Low pay with no room for higher wages Disconnected administration Unmanageable and unfair workload- some have small workloads and others are set up for failure No room for upward mobility

pros: Health Care Benefits, Colleagues, Location, and Open Lab
cons: Insufficient attention Diversity and Inclusion, Tokenism (racial), Poor mental health services for students, lack of focus on international/global programming, Toxic Marketing VP/Administration, Poor Compensation for most full time faculty, Too many VPs and overpaid administration, Lack of Academic Freedom, Lack of shared faculty governance, Dismissive of the Humanities, Focus on VOTECH and students as clients, Administration has little regard for faculty workload/wellbeing, Killing full-time tenure positions in favor of contracts/adjuncts for slave wages, lack of transparency and poor communications, bad promotion guidelines/oversight, weak HR (handling of sexual harassment case, etc.). It used to be a very positive place to work with senior level administration caring deeply for faculty, staff and the values of the university but has declined as a workplace over the last 7 years due to Administration and Senior Management. Such a shame.

pros: Good salary and benefits for the area. Beautiful campus.
cons: Lots of change going on. Uncertain future of higher ed overall. Morale is currently low.

review_title: Miserable and incredibly corrupt and political leaders
pros:
Students

 and

some very well-intentioned colleagues (mostly newer who are not TT or have yet to earn tenure).
cons:
Beautiful campus but investment in renovating or building dorms and classrooms are a mess. The dorms are disgusting. Some classrooms are beautiful and modern, showing off all kinds of tech. Many classes feel like the 1970s. There is no A/C and even the blinds are old, dirty, and cracking with age. 

The worst part though is that there is no leadership and you cannot trust a soul. The president has no respect for the provost (we have had two and both have confided to people that they were regularly stabbed in the back by him) and every AU is run by the inmates! As you can imagine, there is a lot of political maneuvering for resources, promotions, and the like. The Union for tenured faculty (I think every faculty group has one now) is weak. They thought we should be happy with a two percent raise.

Five years ago I uprooted myself and our small family because I was told we were going to be a part of all kinds of unique change. We were told that clusters would set us apart. All it has done is confuse everyone and leave no authority or management throughout the AUs. If I could afford to leave, I would in a blink of an eye. But I have been trapped. I must apply for tenure and then I suppose I will begin adopting the attitude of all these tenured professors who do not appear to give a damn about anything except themselves.

pros: Being alone and making new friends.
cons: It's school and hard also very frustrating. A lot of work.

pros: great location, small and safe community, small class sizes
cons: financial structure unstable, rapid changes ongoing across all level institutional administration and function, very low State support for education

pros:

pros: Excellent people and possibilities at this mid-sized public university.

pros: Working with students from all over the country.
cons: Leadership is poor. Many middle management (Directors) do not actually work and just boss around their staff. Many departments are hostile work environments. Employees are constantly told they are lucky to have a job when constantly being given more work responsibility every time some one quits and they do not rehire to save money.

pros: great co-workers and boss are also fantastic
cons: none that I can think of

pros: Entrepreneurial and opportunity seeking.  Their objective of creating clusters and eliminating departmental boundaries is a good one.
cons: Some people are resistant to change and very conservative.  Leadership sends out contradictory messages.   They hire and fire people constantly.   There is much turmoil among those employees who do not have tenure.

pros: PSU is in a transitional stage.  A new cluster format to the Undergrad setup is moving the university in a solid direction.  President Birx has come in with strong initiatives to revive the alumni community and improve the financial efficiency of the University.  Strong community, plenty of outdoors activities and friendly atmosphere.
cons: Things happen at a slower pace here.  President Birx has done a great deal of good but has leaned up the University's staff a bit so some clearly see this as bad.  Some departments are hesitant to change ways in evolving times.  Still too bureaucratic of an operation for the relatively small size of the institution.

pros: Decent benefits for full-time employees. Long-term employees get lots of time off.
cons: You have to follow "steps/directions" all the time even when there are more efficient ways to accomplish a task. Increases are given to those whose jobs get restructured (new title = new salary).  Otherwise, no raises for the past two years.

pros:
- Excellent customer service experience
- Supervisors are willing to work with your class/life schedule
- Supervisors try hard to educate all members of the team, and are always available for any questions/concerns employees may have.
- Work pace is fast enough to keep you interested, but not overwhelming.
- Work culture is very relaxed and generally pleasant.
- Excellent position progression if you are willing to put in the effort.
- Provides great recommendations after graduating. 
- They are always willing to let you do your own pet projects if you are a IT or CS student at the college.
cons:
- Inter-department communication is not always reliable.
- Professors and students coming to the desk can be difficult.
- Supervisors rarely take action against under preforming or incompetent staff.
- The Help Desk exists in a weird pseudo library position, you will be asked question about the library, books, and other items. This can be irritating because it is technically outside you scope, and is discouraged by the librarians. It can be irritating to the patron however if you attempt to refer them to the actual librarians.
- University politics are absolutely terrible, and can affect your position, hours, and pay.
- Expect new responsibilities to land at your feet whenever things in the library change. Also do not expect the supervisors or upper management to have a worked out plan as to how these new responsibilities should be carried out.

review_title: Slow and steady gets a paycheck
pros: If you are looking to add to your education (free tuition for up to 5 classes per year is covered for full-time employees), or you enjoy the outdoors/skiing, PSU is not a bad place to work. Also, I can't possibly say enough about how many genuinely nice and decent people work at the school
cons:
The ITS department at PSU is particularly talented and has become truly efficient at delivering high-quality solutions at ridiculously low costs (due to constant budget constraints). Despite this, management perceives ITS employees as 'techies' who are unable to see a larger financial picture, and this often results in useful projects remaining unfunded while heaps of money are thrown at useless products sold to unknowing managers by clever salespeople. Evidence of this tension between staff and management can be found in the fact that PSU is about to hire its 3rd CIO in as many years, and that includes a 1+ year vacancy where a suitable candidate could not be found.

Because good work is rarely acknowledged or rewarded (this is not because of supervisors, it is a system-wide policy dictated by the fact that bonuses, gifts, etc. are nearly impossible to give under ethical guidelines), PSU tends to attract people who are more concerned about not losing their jobs than doing a good one. If you are a motivated employee, this can get frustrating fast.

You will be compensated below every possible average, including those generated by independent auditors hired by PSU's administration to prove that PSU employees were being decently-compensated in the face of upcoming budget and benefit cuts. Tech staff are particularly underpaid, about 9% under locality-corrected averages. The only overpaid group? The principal administrators (president, provost, etc). Not a surprise, really.

pros: Beautifully picturesque New England college town. Good work/life balance. Exceptional professional development. The administration is not inaccessible to students or employees. Upper management and middle management take a personal interest in you and your family. Focus on community and student service is apparent throughout the organization.
cons: If you're not used to working in a fast-paced, innovative environment, you may struggle to keep up. The benefits could be better for lower-level employees, but much of that is determined at the USNH level, not within the University itself.

pros: Flexible hours, great people within PE center, great community, athletic funding on the rise to increase facilities.  Very accommodating to my needs as I had to balance a graduate academic schedule.
cons: Small state school in NH means limited funding to be dispersed across many different departments.  Not really that big of a deal but just a fact.

review_title: Good place to work, not well funded
job_title: Help Desk and Customer Service Coordinator in Plymouth, NH
pros: Lots of excellent co-workers.  Pretty good benefits, good retirement, great vacation (after the first 3-5 years).
cons: As with most universities, there are politics and committees that slow progress.  It's a public university in the least funded state in the union, so money is always tight.
